{{Infobox person | name = Luis M. de Llauder y Dalmases | image = Lluís Maria de Llauder i de Dalmases.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Luis Llauder Dalmases | birth_date = 1837 | birth_place = [[Madrid]] | death_date = 1902 | death_place = [[Barcelona]] | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = politician | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = publisher | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Carlism]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | misc = }}
'''Luis Gonzaga María Antonio Carlos Ramón Miguel de Llauder y de Dalmases, de Freixas, de Bufalá y de Camín, 1st marquis of Vallteix''' (1837–1902)<ref>full list of his given names in Jordi Canal, ''Lluís M. de Llauder, cap del carlisme catalá (1888–1902)'', [in:] ''L’Erol'' 76 (2003), p. 30. Present-day Catalan language publications keep Catalanizing his name as "Lluís Llauder i Dalmases"; since he preferred to have been referred to with the Spanish version, compare his signature on ''Carta abierta al Excmo. Sr. General Martínez Campos'', [in:] ''Correo Catalán'' 1 October 1993, p. 15, quoted after Jordi Canal, ''El carlisme català dins l’Espanya de la Restauració'', Vic 1998, {{ISBN|8476022433}}, p. 263, this spelling is followed also here</ref> was a Spanish Catholic publisher and a [[Carlist]] politician. He is known as leader of [[Catalans|Catalan]] Carlism of the late nineteenth century. He is also recognized as founder and the moving spirit behind Barcelona-based Catholic media initiatives, especially a publishing house, a daily ''[[:es:El Correo Catalán|Correo Catalán]]'', and a weekly ''[[:es:La Hormiga de Oro|La Hormiga de Oro]]''.
==Family and youth== [[File:Clos Arqueològic de Torre Llauder 2.jpg|thumbnail|left|''[[:ca:Vil·la romana de Torre Llauder|Torre Llauder]]'' used to stand here]] The Llauders were first recorded in the late 15th century, its representatives noted as blacksmiths based in the Catalan town of [[Argentona]].<ref>Enric Subińà i Coll, ''La Torre Llauder: La masia i els seus propietaris'', [in:] ''XV Sessió Estudis Mataronins. Comunicacions presentades'', Mataró 1998, p. 81</ref> In course of the next two centuries the family grew into prominence and wealth, accumulating a number of estates in [[Mataró]] and [[Barcelona]]; since mid-17th century its senior was honorary citizen of the Catalan capital.<ref>Subińà 1998, p. 82; the city ceased to recognise the title in the early 19th century</ref> In the late 18th century the family built an iconic Mataró mansion known as [[:ca:Vil·la romana de Torre Llauder|Torre Llauder]]<ref>the mansion was sold by Llauder family in 1915 and changed hands a number of times, gradually falling into decrepit condition; though it was declared part of national heritage, half-abandoned it was demolished in 1970, Subińà 1998, pp. 79, 94. Since the early 1960s the plot was site of archeological works; declared remnants of ancient Roman village, in 1980 it was re-arranged as a museum</ref> and kept living there interchanging with the residence at intersection of the Hèrcules and Arlet streets in Barcelona.<ref>Subińà 1998, p. 85</ref> Luis' great-grandfather, José Antonio Llauder y Duran, commenced industrial activities upon receiving concession to exploit water springs;<ref>Subińà 1998, p. 87</ref> despite damages suffered during the [[Peninsular War]], the business was developed further on by his son José Francisco Llauder y Camín, who died in 1824 already as the first taxpayer of Mataró.<ref>Subińà 1998, p. 90</ref> [[File:ULL.87.23.14.jpg|thumbnail|160px|young Llauder]] José Francisco's son and the father of Luis, Ramón de Llauder y Freixes (1807–1870), inherited the family wealth and prestige. He fell in love with María Mercedes de Dalmases y de Bufalà (died 1885),<ref>Subińà 1998, p. 92; for her death date see ''La Hormiga de Oro'' 07.06.85, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0012078479&page=3 here]</ref> also a Catalan native of [[Sant Martí Sesgueioles]],<ref name="Canal 2003, p. 30">Canal 2003, p. 30</ref> descendant to a wealthy [[bourgeoisie]] family.<ref>''El fons del llinatge Massot-Dalmases'', [in:] ''Lo Carranquer'' blog 31.03.15, available [http://locarranquer.blogspot.com/2015/03/el-fons-del-llinatge-massot-dalmases.html here]</ref> The couple married in 1837<ref>Subińà 1998, p. 92; the 1837 date of marriage seems somewhat odd, given their son Luis was born in May 1837</ref> and initially settled in Madrid,<ref>though most sources claim that Llauder was born in Madrid, according to one author it was in Mataró, Francisco de Paula, ''Album de Personajes Carlistas con sus Biografias'', volume II, Barcelona 1888, vol. 2, p. 183</ref> but they soon moved to the Llauder residence in Barcelona; Ramon remained the first taxpayer of Mataró.<ref name="Subińà 1998, p. 92">Subińà 1998, p. 92</ref> Apart from integration and further development of the family businesses, he made his name as a lawyer and became member of [[Supreme Court of Spain|Tribunal Supremo]].<ref name="Subińà 1998, p. 92"/> He is known as a fervent Catholic who donated large sums to the Church, including financing of a newly set up [[Poor Clares]] convent. Ramon demonstrated interest in charity, further developed also by Luis, e.g. founding and financing a school for the poor.<ref>Subińà 1998, pp. 92-3</ref>
Ramon and María had 6 children, except Luis all of them daughters;<ref>María Candelària, María Assumpció, María del Àngels, María Ignàcia and Pilar</ref> they were brought up in fervently Catholic ambience. One of them, Pilar, became nun of the [[Handmaids of the Sacred Heart of Jesus]] order.<ref>Subińà 1998, p. 93, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 22.03.82, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000062151&page=3 here]</ref> It is not clear where the young Luis received his schooling; he obtained bachillerato in 1851.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 253</ref> He then enrolled at the Civil and Canon law faculty of the [[Universitat de Barcelona]], graduating as licenciado in 1858;<ref>''La Corona'' 18.12.58, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026730994&page=8 here]</ref> one source claims he received technical education and graduated as engineer.<ref>Begoña Urigüen, ''Orígenes y evolución de la derecha española: el neo-catolicismo'', Madrid 1986, {{ISBN|9788400061579}}, p. 323</ref> As he inherited a real estate fortune and the industry enterprises, it is not clear whether he has ever practiced as a lawyer. He has never married and had no children.<ref name="Subińà 1998, p. 93">Subińà 1998, p. 93</ref> A little known poet of the early 20th century, Lorenzo de Llauder y de Bonilla, was his distant relative.<ref>he was grandson of Luis’ grandfather's brother, see Enrique Toral y Fernández de Peñaranda, ''Vida y obra del poeta giennense de los floreos, don Lorenzo de Llauder y de Bonilla, quinto Marqués del Valle de Ribas'', [in:] ''Boletín del Instituto de Estudios Giennenses'' 180 (2002), pp. 545-572</ref>
==Early public activity== [[File:CAZ,18.17.jpg|thumbnail|left|160px|''La Convicción'']] There is little information on Llauder's public activity in the 1860s. He was certainly active in various Catholic groupings; having inherited from his father vivid interest in social issues and a penchant for charity, in 1863 he was acknowledged as engaged in Caridad Cristiana, a Barcelona philanthropic institution specializing in education; in the early 1864 he rose to deputy treasurer of the organization.<ref>''La Corona'' 05.02.64, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026775253&page=8 here]</ref> Llauder was also noted as active in regional realm in-between economy and public management: in 1865 he was secretary of comisión organizadora preparing an agricultural exposition in Mataró; within this body he represented the proprietors.<ref>''La Corona'' 24.07.65, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026783215&page=5 here]</ref> There is a source which claims that in his youth he practiced as a lawyer, though the information is not confirmed elsewhere.<ref>"durante su juventud había sido un abogado distinguido", ''El Deber'' 14.06.02, available [http://pandora.bibgirona.cat/viewer.vm?id=0000142211&page=16 here]</ref> He was probably engaged also in the family business; at unspecified time and under his guidance the number of family operated watermills rose from 2 to 5; he also upgraded some of them by mounting auxiliary steam engines.<ref name="Subińà 1998, p. 93"/>
It is not clear when Llauder commenced his lifelong career of a publisher and a journalist.<ref>a hagiographic piece claims that "en 1866 empezó a distinguirse ya como periodista", B. de Artagan [Reynaldo Brea], ''Políticos del carlismo'', Barcelona 1912, p. 105</ref> One author maintains that it was "shortly after" graduation when he tried his hand in letters, starting co-operation with local periodicals.<ref>Canal 2003, p. 30; some authors claim he commenced writing in 1866, see Artagan 1912, p. 105</ref> The first titles named are popular Catholic reviews ''La Sociedad Católica'',<ref>a Madrid based daily launched in 1865; he managed it at unspecified time before it ceased in 1867, José Navarro Cabanes, ''Apuntes bibliográficos de la prensa carlista'', Valencia 1917, p. 51</ref> ''El Amigo del Pueblo'' and ''El Criterio Católico'',<ref>a Barcelona based daily launched in 1866, Navarro 1917, p. 51</ref> and the time is specified as "second half of the 1860s".<ref>''El Deber'' 14.06.02, available [http://pandora.bibgirona.cat/viewer.vm?id=0000142211&page=16 here], Canal 2003, p. 30, Canal 1998, p. 256</ref> It seems that at that time he was formatted as a militant Catholic author rather than a partisan of any specific party. His opinion on politics of the era, especially on the crumbling rule of [[Isabel II of Spain|Isabel II]], is not known. It was only the [[Glorious Revolution (Spain)|Glorious Revolution]] of 1868 and declaration of the [[First Spanish Republic]] that triggered Llauder's political career. [[File:Charles of Bourbon in Mundo Gráfico.jpg|thumbnail|160px|young [[Carlos, Duke of Madrid|Carlos VII]]]] There were no known Carlist antecedents in Llauder's family. Political views of his father are unclear, while his paternal uncle, [[Carlos de Llauder y Freixes]], was well established in the Isabelline system as a [[Partido Moderado]] politician and a [[Cortes Generales|Cortes]] deputy.<ref>see official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXLDA.fmt&DOCS=1-25&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&QUERY=%2861240%29.NDIP. here]</ref> It was rather the brother of his paternal grandfather, [[:es:Manuel Llauder|Manuel de Llauder y Camín]], who gained nationwide recognition as a Carlist foe; when capitán general of Catalonia he made his name for engineering anti-Carlist repressions during and after the [[First Carlist War]].<ref>Artagan 1912, p. 105; for his own account see ''Memorias documentadas del teniente coronel don Manuel Llauder'', Madrid 1844, available [https://books.google.es/books?id=GOwCAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&client=firefox-a&source=gbs_v2_summary_r&hl=pl#v=onepage&q&f=false here]</ref> Hence, it is not clear how Llauder approached the Carlists in the late 1860s. Later party propaganda claimed that it was his bright intelligence that made him conclude, somewhat against the family background, that [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalism]] was the only way forward.<ref>"sobrino del famoso general Llauder, uno de los que más persiguieron a los legitimistas en la guerra civil, habiéndose educado al lado de parienres moderados, su inteligencia previsora, su gran conocimiento de las cosas y de los hombres a pesar de los pocos anos que cuenta, le hicieron comprender que la única salvación del pais estaba en la bandera legitimista", El Vizconde de la Esperanza [Julio Nombela ], ''La Bandera Carlista en 1871'', Madrid 1871, p. 305, quoted after Canal 2003, pp. 33-4</ref> This became evident in his 1869 booklet, ''El desenlace de la revolución españoIa''. The work compared regimes of liberal monarchy, republic and traditionalist monarchy. Stemming mostly from Catholic principles, it declared Traditionalism the only viable option, advocating leadership of the Carlist claimant [[Carlos, Duke of Madrid|Carlos VII]]. ''Desenlace'' was focused on politics; the work by no means endorsed violence, the position that Llauder was to maintain through all later life.<ref>Canal 1998, pp. 253-4</ref> According to his own later accounts, the book was the first attempt "to fly the Carlist standard in Catalonia" during the [[Sexenio Democrático]].<ref name="Canal 2003, p. 30"/>
==Approach to, Third Carlist War and aftermath== [[File:Carlist deputies and senators 1871.JPG|thumbnail|160px|left|Llauder and Carlist MPs]] ''Desenlace'' earned Llauder his name in Catalan public discourse. He was welcomed in Asociación Católico-Monárquica,<ref>by the Carlist veteran Ramón Cabrera it was envisioned as a Carlist legal outpost and possibly a Spanish version of the English Tories, Urigüen 1986, p. 312</ref> an agglutinatory force attracting far-Right opposition. The formation was an alliance of [[:es:Neocatólico|neo-Catholics]], Conservatives and Carlists; though Llauder's non-belligerent stance was similar to that of the neos, a contemporary scholar clearly identifies him as a Carlist.<ref>Urigüen 1986, p. 323</ref> In the supplementary 1870 elections to Cortes Constituentes Llauder appeared on candidatura católico-monárquica in his native district of [[Vic]]h.<ref>Urigüen 1986, p. 320</ref> When elected<ref>see the 1870 mandate at official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=1-1&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2861250%29.NDIP. here].</ref> he joined the 23-member Carlist minority.<ref>Urigüen 1986, p. 327</ref> In the successive 1871 campaign he ran<ref>according to his later account, the objective was not to govern or share power, but to protest Republican injustice towards religion and society, Urigüen 1986, pp. 429-30</ref> on the same ticket from [[Berga]], elected with 97% of all votes cast.<ref>see the 1871 mandate at official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=2-2&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2861250%29.NDIP. here]</ref> In the spring of 1872 he again stood in Berga;<ref>''La Esperanza'' 22.03.72, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002540678&page=1 here]</ref> though initially reported victorious,<ref>''El Imparcial'' 09.04.72, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000488778&page=1 here]</ref> in unclear circumstances he was finally declared defeated.<ref>the victorious candidate gained only 34% of the votes cast, see the 1872 Berga mandate at official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDBuscHisDip?_piref73_1340033_73_1340032_1340032.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXDSP.fmt&DOCS=1-1&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&QUERY=%40ELEN%26gt%3B%3D%2229%22+%26+%40ELEN%26lt%3B%3D%2230%22+%26+%28%22BERGA%22%29.DIST. here] also ''La Epoca'' 10.04.72, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000294164&page=2 here]</ref>
In the early 1870s Llauder's career of a publisher was already in full swing. Around 1870<ref>according to most scholars, but one source claims the correct date is 1868, Solange Hibbs-Lissorgues, ''La prensa católica catalana de 1868 a 1900 (II)'', [in:] ''Anales de Literatura Española'' 9 (1993), p. 97, also Navarro 1917, p. 59</ref> he founded with his own money a Barcelona-based daily ''La Convicción'',<ref name="de Paula 1888, p. 184">de Paula 1888, p. 184</ref> acting also as a manager and [[editor-in-chief]] until the title was closed in 1873.<ref>Canal 2003, p. 30 Urigüen 1986, p. 351, Solange Hibbs-Lissorgues, ''La prensa católica catalana de 1868 a 1900 (I)'', [in:] ''Anales de Literatura Española'' 7 (1991), p. 105</ref> Though the paper demonstrated clear Traditionalist leaning, its political strategy appear confusing. On the one hand Llauder demonstrated much flexibility. In 1871 he advocated alliance of all opposition groupings; the call raised eyebrows of those - like [[:es:Francisco Navarro Villoslada|Navarro Villoslada]] - who were surprised at having been encouraged to join ranks with the radical republicans.<ref>Urigüen 1986, pp. 429-30</ref> On the other hand, Llauder demonstrated a doctrinaire position when lambasting the neo-Catholic [[:es:José María Quadrado|José María Quadrado]]<ref>who claimed that one can be a good Catholic not being a Carlist</ref> by calling him a liberal disciple of [[François-René de Chateaubriand|Chateaubriand]].<ref>he wrote that Carlist standard was "en la cual el católico puede esperar tranquilamente la muerte sin que tenga que hacer retractaciones y arrepentirse de otra cosa que no haver luchado bastante pos su triunfo", Urigüen 1986, pp. 351-2</ref> Scholars present different views on Llauder's position versus amalgamation with the neo-Catholics; some claim he opposed it<ref>a present-day scholar claims that while [[:es:Joan Mañé i Flaquer|Juan Mañé y Flaquer]] represented the Carlist press sympathetic towards a merger with the Neos, Llauder stood for the branch opposing it, Urigüen 1986, p. 351</ref> and some claim he himself approached them.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 23</ref> At that time he was already considered "prestigioso periodista".<ref>Urigüen 1986, p. 460</ref> [[File:1872 nafarroa.jpg|thumbnail|160px|Carlist subjects, 1870s]] Shortly before outbreak of the [[Third Carlist War]] Llauder was an eminent party figure in Catalonia, rising to presidency of the Barcelona Ateneo Católico-monárquica<ref>''La Esperanza'' 02.03.72, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002540174&page=1 here]</ref> and Junta Provincial Católico-monárquica.<ref>his deputy was Rafael de Llanza, ''La Regeneración'' 02.03.72, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026701939&page=1 here]</ref> Since 1870 he was living intermittently in Spain and abroad, mostly in the [[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[Vevey]], where he accompanied the claimant and his brother [[Alfonso Carlos, Duke of San Jaime|Don Alfonso Carlos]].<ref name="de Paula 1888, p. 184"/> At the outbreak of hostilities as a renowned propagandist he felt endangered by republican militants and did not return to Spain.<ref>''La Convicción'' 15.08.72, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004147345&page=1 here], also Artagan 1912, p. 105</ref> His exact war record is not clear, though he probably did not take part in hostilities. At least temporarily he accompanied Carlos VII in [[Gipuzkoa]];<ref name="de Paula 1888, p. 184"/> in mid-1873 the press reported him as nominated secretary to Alfonso Carlos,<ref>''La Discussión'' 29.05.73, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002422024&page=2 here]</ref> though later he was noted as resident in the French [[Prats-de-Mollo]], active within a group of recovering Carlist combatants.<ref>''La Esperanza'' 07.10.75, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002562009&page=3 here]</ref> No further information is available; one scholar summarizes his contribution to the Carlist war effort as "modestíssima".<ref>Canal 1998, p. 31</ref>
Following the Carlist defeat Llauder did not return to Spain. In 1876 the claimant nominated him secretary to Junta de Generales,<ref name="de Paula 1888, p. 184"/> a rather ineffective makeshift Carlist executive set up by Carlos VII prior to his departure to America. Some sources claim that until 1878 he permanently resided in [[Rome]], acting as sort of a Carlist diplomatic envoy to [[Holy See|Vatican]],<ref>de Paula 1888, pp. 184-5</ref> though contemporary press noticed his taking part in the 1877 pilgrimage to [[Zaragoza]].<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 19.07.77, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000023122&page=1 here]</ref>
==Nocedalista== [[File:Candido Nocedal.JPG|thumbnail|160px|left|[[:es:Cándido Nocedal|Candido Noceda]]l]] Back in Spain Llauder resumed public activity in the Carlist realm. It was very much pursued along the lines set up by [[:es:Cándido Nocedal|Candido Nocedal]], who intended to format the party as focused on religious issues and vehemently opposed to the emerging [[Restoration (Spain)|Restauración]] regime. Already shortly after the military defeat Llauder joined Nocedal in a plot, aimed against Junta de Generales, and served as liaison with a number of distinguished Carlist figures.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 41, Javier Real Cuesta, ''El Carlismo Vasco 1876–1900'', Madrid 1985, {{ISBN|9788432305108}}, pp. 4-5, 11-12</ref> Once Nocedal was appointed the official jefe delegado in 1879, Llauder emerged as top Catalan exponent of his political line, known as [[Integrism (Spain)|Integrism]]. Since key nocedalista means of mobilization were public events styled as Catholic feasts, especially pilgrimages, in 1879 Llauder became member of Junta Directiva organizing another massive excursion to Rome.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 14.11.79, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000047818&page=1 here]</ref> As initial plan did not work out, in 1882 he headed Barcelona branch of junta organizadora engineering the next attempt,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 14.01.83, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000060006&page=2 here]</ref> and once political nature of the enterprise became evident, he was confronted by the Barcelona bishop [[:es:José María Urquinaona|José María Urquinaona]].<ref>Canal 1998, pp. 47-8</ref>
Nocedal and his followers envisioned Carlism as a loose movement, its direction set by a wide range of publications; in 1875 in Madrid they founded a daily which was to become an icon of Traditionalist press, ''[[El Siglo Futuro]]''. Llauder followed suit in Barcelona, where in 1878 he took over ''Correo Catalán''. ''Correo'' started to serve as the principal Integrist tribune in Catalonia; it published articles of key Catholic intransigents like [[Félix Sardà y Salvany]],<ref>Canal 1998, p. 44, Canal 2003, p. 31</ref> joined ''El Siglo Futuro'' in war against other Carlist publications like ''Le Fé'', representing competitive religious and political vision,<ref>Canal 1998, pp. 43, 51</ref> and co-engineered campaign against the [[:es:Alejandro Pidal y Mon|Pidalistas]], who decided to join political structures of the regime.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 50</ref> His belligerency cost Llauder legal action<ref>for attacking Alfonso XII personally</ref> and incarceration sentence;<ref>he avoided prison thanks to paying a 5,000 peseta penalty</ref> ''Correo'', suspended for 45 days, was at that time replaced by ephemeral ''El Noticiero''.<ref>Navarro 1917, p. 131</ref> Soon Llauder threw himself into publishing activity altogether: in 1883 he set up an intransigent Catholic weekly,<ref>the first issue appeared in January 1884, Raquel Arias Durá, ''Revista ''La Hormiga de Oro''. Análisis documental'', [in:] ''Revista General de Información y Documentación'' 24-1 (2014), p. 187</ref> in 1885 he opened a bookstore,<ref name="Arias 2014, p. 186">Arias 2014, p. 186</ref> and in 1887 he complemented the business by founding a publishing house, all named ''La Hormiga de Oro''.<ref name="Arias 2014, p. 188">Arias 2014, p. 188</ref> [[File:CAZ18.18.jpg|thumbnail|''La Hormiga de Oro'' bookstore]] In the mid-1880s Llauder seemed fully aligned with the Integrist vision and its key components: intransigent Catholicism, political abstention, and Carlism understood primarily as a platform of religious mobilization. He self-declared himself an Integrist, writing with pride that "only a small group of faithful disciples followed the Church [...]. This group was called integristas, intransigentes or tradicionalistas".<ref>Hibbs-Lissorgues 1993, p. 89</ref> He took part in number of formal Integrist-defined and Integrist-named public initiatives,<ref>''La Unión'' 18.06.83, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004865540&page=2 here]</ref> let alone co-operation between ''Correo Catalán'' and ''El Siglo Futuro'',<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 03.02.83, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000066019&page=1 here]</ref> his daily representing an exclusivist, hard-line, [[Hardline|machamartillo]] format of religiosity. By scholars he is clearly considered as "member of the Integrist sector of the party".<ref>Jordi Canal i Morell, ''Carlins i integristes a la Restauració: l’escissió de 1888'', [in:] ''Revista de Girona'' 147 (1991), p. 63</ref> However, apart from continuing ''guerra periodistica'', Llauder is not recognized for confronting the competitive group, led by [[Enrique de Aguilera y Gamboa|marqués de Cerralbo]] and known as aperturistas, and is not considered protagonist of increasingly bitter strife between the warring factions.
==Breakup of 1888== [[File:Ramon Nocedal.JPG|thumbnail|160px|left|[[Ramón Nocedal Romea|Ramón Nocedal]]]] In early 1888 the claimant invited Llauder to his [[Venice]] residence and asked to prepare a publication which would clarify the official royal position. His personal choice might have seemed surprising given Llauder's role in Integrism, as Nocedal's son [[Ramón Nocedal Romea|Ramón]] clearly aimed at reducing the claimant to a decorative role. Some scholars claim that Carlos VII picked Llauder considering him an in-between person who would act as mediator between the two factions.<ref>José Andres Gallego, ''La politica religiosa en España'', Madrid 1975, p. 29</ref> Other students suggest that the Carlist king intended to outplay the Nocedalistas by luring into his camp one of their politicians, and that choosing Llauder was a smart deceiving move.<ref>Jordi Canal, ''El carlismo'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|8420639478}}, p. 228</ref>
The publication took shape of a March 1888 article in ''Correo Catalán'', titled ''El Pensamiento del Duque de Madrid'';<ref>Agustín Fernández Escudero, ''El marqués de Cerralbo (1845–1922): biografía politica'' [PhD thesis], Madrid 2012, p. 100</ref> it was styled as an interview with the claimant.<ref>it was possibly based on the actual interview that Llauder held with Carlos VI during a Catalan pilgrimage to Rome, Andres Gallego 1975, p. 51</ref> Apart from doctrinal issues it urged moderation, respect for other Traditionalists and stated that no daily could speak for the king.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 64, Canal 2003, p. 31</ref> Instead of reconciliation, it led to escalation; Nocedal and his supporters left Carlism and set up their own party. Though the breakup did not have a major effect on the rank-and-file, it devastated Carlist network of periodicals; most editorial boards decided to side with the secessionists.<ref>Jordi Canal i Morell, ''La masonería en el discurso integrista español a fines del siglo XIX: Ramón Nocedal y Romea'', [in:] J. A. Ferrer Benimeli (ed.), ''Masonería, revolución y reacción'' vol. 2, Alicante 1990, {{ISBN|844047606X}}, p. 778</ref> Llauder's position came as a surprise: for 10 years one of the most prestigious Nocedals' supporters, he decided not to join them and to stand by his king.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 279</ref> [[File:Carlos Duke of Madrid.jpg|thumbnail|160px|Carlos VII, probably around 1890]] Llauder's motives are not entirely clear; it seems that out of two features constituting his previous position, the Integrist outlook and the loyalty to Carlist dynasty, the latter prevailed.<ref>Canal 2003, p. 31</ref> His stand came as a nasty surprise for the Nocedalistas, who declared Llauder a traitor.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 74, Canal 2003, p. 31</ref> When striking back<ref>Canal 1998, p. 68</ref> he played down ideological differences and tended to define the conflict as result of overgrown personal ambitions of Nocedal. Also in case of Sarda Llauder confirmed validity of his works, noting that the author took unduly advantage of his prestige.<ref>Canal 1998, pp. 280-1</ref> In general, he tended to approach the Integrists as a sick branch of a healthy tree and later tried to exercise some moderating influence; following clashes in the [[:ca:Teatre Olimp|Olimpo theatre]] in 1889<ref>details in Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 114</ref> he criticized Carlists taking part and demanded they do not respond to provocations.<ref>Canal 1998, pp. 74-5</ref>
As the breakaway Nocedalistas controlled ''El Siglo Futuro'', previously the national party mouthpiece,<ref>in a bitter guerra periodistica which ensued he became one of prime targets for the Integrist propaganda; ''El Siglo Futuro'' did not spare him any charge and insult Fernández Escudero 2012, pp. 123, 128, Jordi Canal i Morell, ''Banderas blancas, boinas rojas: una historia política del carlismo, 1876–1939'', Madrid 2006, {{ISBN|9788496467347}}, pp. 166-7</ref> Carlos VII decided to set a new semi-official Carlist newspaper; this role was entrusted to Llauder, who in 1888–1889 moved to [[Madrid]].<ref>Canal 1998, p. 257, Canal 2003, p. 32</ref> Initially to be named ''El Estandarte Real'',<ref>and based on staff consisting of Leandro Herrero, Valbuena y Somoza Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 127, Canal 1998, pp. 134-5</ref> the daily materialized in 1888 as ''[[El Correo Español (1888-1922)|El Correo Español]]'', largely modeled on ''Correo Catalán'' and by some considered its "brother newspaper".<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 108</ref> Following successful launch, in 1889 Llauder transferred ownership to the claimant,<ref>Canal 1998, p. 136, Canal 2003, p. 33</ref> ceded management to [[Leandro Herrero]]<ref>Canal 1998, p. 144, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 134</ref> and moved back to Barcelona.<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 128, Canal 2000, p. 232</ref> According to some, it was Llauder who offered job in the editorial board to [[Juan Vázquez de Mella]].<ref>opinion of Jesús Pabón, referred after Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 129</ref> Though in the early 1890s some suggested that Llauder takes back leadership of the newspaper, suffering from capricious de Mella's management,<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 132</ref> the daily proved a lasting enterprise and closed as late as 1922.<ref>Agustín Fernández Escudero, ''El XVII marqués de Cerralbo (1845–1922). Primera parte de la historia de un noble carlista, desde 1869 hasta 1900'', [in:] ''Ab Initio: Revista digital para estudiantes de Historia'', 2 (2011), p. 139</ref>
==Catalan Jefe== [[File:De Cerralbo.JPG|thumbnail|160px|left|[[Enrique de Aguilera y Gamboa|marques de Cerralbo]]]] The new party leader de Cerralbo pursued his own vision of Carlism, focused on organizational build-up. Its initial embodiment were structures officially created to co-ordinate Carlist celebrations of the so-called [[:es:Conversión de Recaredo|Conversión de Recaredo]]; in 1889 Llauder was nominated Catalan representative in Junta Central<ref>Canal 1998, p. 78</ref> and head of Catalan Junta Regional.<ref>Jordi Canal, ''¿En busca del precedente perdido? Tríptico sobre las complejas relaciones entre carlismo y catalanismo a fines del siglo XIX'', [in:] ''Historia y Politica'' 14 (2005), p. 46, Canal 1998, p. 79, Canal 2003, p. 31, Canal 2006, p. 200, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 145</ref> Though the nomination was protested by those who remembered his anti-belligerent stand in the 1870s<ref>mostly supporters of Felip de Sabater, who had military record in the Third Carlist War and counted among key Catalan Carlists</ref> and those who resented his alliance with the Integros in the 1880s,<ref>Canal 1998, p. 84, Canal 2003, pp. 31-2</ref> in 1890 Llauder was confirmed as President of new official Junta Regional Carlista.<ref>Aratagan 1917, p. 107</ref>
In Catalonia Llauder presided over transformation of Carlism from a loose movement into a modern and efficient party. In line with Cerralbo's strategy he worked towards setting local structures, encouraging new juntas whenever possible.<ref>“en los pueblos de mas corto vecindario”, Canal 1998, p. 94, also Jordi Canal, ''La revitalización política del carlismo a fines del siglo XIX: los viajes de propaganda del Marqués de Cerralbo'', [in:] ''Studia Zamorensia'' 3 (1996), p. 256; Llauder liste a number of reasons to set up he circulos, Canal 1998, p. 182. For detailed discussion of their role see Canal 1998, pp. 179-216</ref> He proved very efficient: in 1892 Catalonia boasted 43 circulos out of 102 existing in Spain;<ref>no province in Spain was comparable to Barcelona (18 circulos) and Tarragona (16), Canal 1998, p. 100</ref> in 1896 the number grew to 100 out of 298, with [[Barcelona province]] leading the way with 46 circulos.<ref>Valencia came second with 45 and Tarragona third with 27 circulos, Canal 1998, p. 100</ref> According to Llauder himself, along [[Navarre]] the countryside of [[muntanya catalana (socio-cultural term)|muntanya catalana]] turned the very heartland of Spanish Carlism.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 101</ref> First Juventud section, a new juvenile branch, was created in Barcelona in 1894.<ref>6 years after the first Juventud, set up in Madrid, Canal 1998, p. 115</ref>
Though in general he remained antiparliamentarian and considered elections a secondary issue,<ref>Canal 2003, p. 32</ref> sort of front cover-up for Liberal backstage rule,<ref>he considered universal suffrage a farce, as he believed the government would never allow the rule of truly popular parties (he counted Carlism among these), Canal 1998, pp. 119-20</ref> he engaged in Carlist electoral effort, resumed by de Cerralbo for the first time in the [[Spanish general election, 1891|1891 campaign]].<ref>Llauder noted that 19 years of inactivity made people forget the value of their vote, Canal 1998, p. 118, Canal 2003, p. 32</ref> When acknowledging rather poor results at the pools in 1891 (2 MPs),<ref>Canal 1998, p. 120, Canal 2003, p. 32</ref> [[Spanish general election, 1896|1896]] (2)<ref>Canal 1998, p. 127</ref> and [[Spanish general election, 1898|1898]] (2),<ref>Canal 1998, p. 128</ref> let alone the disastrous [[Spanish general election, 1893|1893 campaign]] (no mandate),<ref>Canal 1998, pp. 126-7</ref> he noted it would have been absurd to conclude that Carlism enjoyed so limited support, blaming fraud for the poor showing.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 121, Fernández Escudero 2012, pp. 244, 251</ref> Himself he stood in his old constituency of Berga and was successful in 1891,<ref>he succeeded partly thanks to divisions among the Liberals and low turnover, Canal 1998, p. 121</ref> but lost in 1893.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 126, Canal 2003, p. 32, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 249</ref> In 1896 he successfully ran for [[Senate (Spain)|Senate]] from [[Girona]],<ref>Canal 1998, p. 255; he was one of 4 Carlists in the Senate, along Cerralbo, Solferino (ensured seat thanks to their grandeza de España) and Tirso Olazabal (also elected), Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 253</ref> but on the claimant's order he refused to take oath<ref>see the official Senate service, available [http://www.senado.es/web/conocersenado/senadohistoria/senado18341923/senadores/fichasenador/index.html?id1=5145&id2=N here]</ref> and signed ''Manifiesto de las minorias carlistas'';<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 320</ref> by some sources he is not listed as a senator.<ref>see e.g. Isidre Molas, ''Els senadors carlins de Catalunya (1901–1923)'', Barcelona 2009</ref> [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|Carlist standard]] During his 14-year leadership of Catalan Carlism Llauder emerged as one of key party heavyweights of the late 19th century.<ref name="Canal 2005, p. 46">Canal 2005, p. 46</ref> He is considered principal agent of ''carlismo nuevo'' in the region;<ref>Canal 1998, p. 92</ref> Catalonia was the first stage of innovative Cerralbo's tours across the country<ref>Canal 1996, pp. 259-260; Llauder was not renown as public speaker himself, though at times he had to delivere public addresses due to his high position in the party, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 176</ref> and Llauder worked hand-in-hand with jefe delegado to implement new peaceful strategy and defuse conspiracy which aimed at renewing violence.<ref>dormant Carlist military structures existed, but were incomaparable to official party network. Small Carlist groups in Catalonia kept accumulating weapons, gearing up for another uprising, Canal 1998, p. 129. Indeed in few cases official authorities banned planned Carlist activities due to fear of unrest, Canal 1998, pp. 129-130. Llauder tried to keep the hot-heads in check. Though he did not exclude violence as a last measure, he considered Carlist primary task to be effective politically, so that violence does not stand a chance of erupting, Canal 1998, p. 289</ref> He hugely contributed to smooth recovery of Catalan Carlism from the Nocedalista crisis; though Llauder had to cope with internal conflict;<ref>e.g. the fronda of Salvador Soliva in 1895-7, Canal 1998, p. 109; there were also controversies over appointing jefes of local circulos instead of having them elected, Canal 1998, pp. 109-113</ref> he played vital role in party consolidation of the 1890.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 85</ref> His 1897 contribution to [[Acta de Loredan]] became last Llauder's major public engagement;<ref>Canal 1998, p. 290</ref> starting 1898 due to rapidly deteriorating health<ref>he developed meningoencefalitis, Canal 2006, p. 196</ref> he was spending long periods in the spa of [[:ca:Serra de Cardó|Cardó]]<ref name="Canal 1998, p. 257">Canal 1998, p. 257</ref> and his regional leadership became largely theoretical. In 1898 the claimant declared him marqués de Vallteix.<ref>Canal 2003, p. 33</ref> No scholar mentions Llauder discussing [[:es:Sublevación carlista de octubre de 1900|Carlist 1900 revolts in Catalonia]], which suggests that shortly before death - still official jefe - he already played no major role in politics.
==Publisher== [[File:Correo Espanol and Correo Catalan.jpg|thumbnail|left|''brother newspapers'']] Though he owned, managed and edited a number of periodicals, including ''La Convicción'' in 1870–1873 and ''El Correo Español'' in 1888–1889, as a publisher Llauder is first and foremost recognized as the moving spirit behind two enterprises which turned into monumental periodical prints in Catalonia, the daily ''Correo Catalán'' and the weekly ''La Hormiga de Oro''; both issued for more than half a century, both outlived him by 34 years.<ref>they went into print until 1936, when their premises were overtaken by Republican militias</ref>
''Correo Catalán'', started in 1876,<ref>by Manuel Milá de la Roca</ref> was taken over by Llauder in 1878.<ref name="Canal 1998, p. 143">Canal 1998, p. 143</ref> Unlike ''Correo Español'', launched with official party finances,<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 129</ref> ''Correo Catalán'' was Llauder's private property. He remained also chief editor of the daily, formatted as continuation of ''La Convicción''.<ref>Hibbs-Lissorgues 1993, p. 106; some sources claim that ''Correo Catalán'' was simply continuation of ''La Convicción'', see ''Lluís Maria de Llauder i de Dalmases'' entry [in:] ''Gran enciclopèdia catalana'' online, available [http://www.enciclopedia.cat/EC-GEC-0037578.xml here]</ref> During the first decade it followed the Integrist line of Nocedal and Sarda;<ref>Canal 1998, p. 255</ref> though after 1888 the daily remained within mainstream Traditionalism,<ref name="Canal 1998, p. 143"/> it very much kept pursuing the same intransigent Catholic line.<ref>Llauder „había asumido la fusión tácita y táctica de los carlistas ortodoxos y los neocatólicos integristas”, José María Paz Gago, ''Una nota sobre la ideología de Pardo Bazán. Doña Emilia, entre el carlismo integrista y el carlismo moderado'', [in:] ''La Tribuna. Cadernos de estudios de Casa Museo Emilia Pardo Bazán'' 5 (2007), p. 350</ref> ''Correo'' remained a semi-official party paper in Catalonia, publishing orders and dispositions, mobilizing organizational work and disseminating propaganda.<ref>Canal 2006, p. 185</ref> It chiefly consisted of 3 sections: news, opinion and fixed columns, dominated by religious subjects.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 145, Canal 2003, p. 33</ref> The daily developed weekly mutations in [[Tarragona]], Girona and [[Lleida]].<ref>Canal 1998, p. 145</ref> Its circulation is not clear; some sources claim 4,000 copies<ref name="Arias 2014, p. 186"/> and some claim as much as 8,000 copies.<ref>Joan Bonet i Balta, ''L'integrisme a Catalunya. Les grans polemiques: 1881–1888'', Barcelona 1990, p. 19, referred after Hibbs-Lissorgues 1993, p. 98</ref> Personal Llauder's trademark were his Sunday editorials.<ref name="Canal 2005, p. 46"/> In 1899 he ceded command of the paper to Salvador Morales.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 145; following Llauder’s death ''Correo Catalán'' became the property of Fomento de la Prensa Tradicionalista and was re-launched by [[Manuel de Llanza y Pignatelli|Solferino]] with Junyent appointed its manager</ref> [[File:CAZ.18.17.jpg|thumbnail|160px|''[[:es:La Hormiga de Oro|La Hormiga de Oro]]'', sample from 1899]] The 1884-launched ''La Hormiga de Oro''<ref name="Arias 2014, p. 187">Arias 2014, p. 187</ref> was among innovative periodicals on the Spanish market;<ref>among ''La Ilustración Española y Americana'', ''Blanco y Negro'', ''Nuevo Mundo'', ''Mundo Gráfico'', Arias 2014, p. 185</ref> published in A3, they combined text and high-quality graphics,<ref>full list of graphic artists Arias 2014, p. 191, list of photographers Arias 2014, p. 192</ref> first drawings and since early 1890s also photographs.<ref>the first photo was published in 1891, Arias 2014, p. 190</ref> The weekly aspired to the role of popular enciclopedia educativa;<ref>Arias 2014, p. 190</ref> its contents comprised news, information, history, letters, arts, politics, though it was dominated by religion-related topics.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 148, Canal 2003, p. 33</ref> Key difference between ''Hormiga'' and likewise reviews was its confessional nature;<ref>Arias 2014, p. 187. "Cuatro son las bestias negras de la selecta publicación de Luis María Llauder: en política, el liberalismo; en religión, la masonería; en historia, la revolución francesa, y en literatura, el naturalismo", Paz Gago 2007, p. 350</ref> it was intended to disseminate Christian thought by means of affordable modern media. Carlism, though present, did not form a leading thread.<ref>Arias 2014, p. 193; some authors claim that ''Hormiga'' played key role in Carlist propaganda machinery of the late 19th century, Canal 1996, p. 251</ref> Distribution included Spain, [[Portugal]], [[Philippines]] and [[Latin America]],<ref name="Arias 2014, p. 187"/> the number of subscribers estimated at 4,000;<ref name="Arias 2014, p. 186"/> in the early 20th century it was one of 6 reviews with the highest circulation in Spain.<ref>Arias 2014, p. 193</ref> Llauder did not run ''Hormiga'', ceding management to different directors.<ref>full list in Arias 2014, p. 187</ref>
The power plant behind Llauder's periodicals<ref>the house issued another daily, ''La Exposición Vaticana llustrada'' (1887-9)</ref> was his publishing house ''La Hormiga de Oro'', founded in 1887;<ref name="Arias 2014, p. 188"/> of three similar Carlist enterprises in Catalonia it was the most stable and the most durable one.<ref>there were three Carlist publishing houses in Catalonia, apart from ''Hormiga'' also ''Biblioteca Tradicionalista'', owned by Francesc de Paula Oller (existing in 1889–1892), and ''Biblioteca Regional'' (1897–1901), owned by Josep Font i Fargas</ref> With a dedicated book shop serving as a front-end customer interface,<ref name="book shop" /> the conglomerate demonstrated that Llauder was fully conscious of the commencing mass culture era. Its business soundness is unclear. It remains striking that Llauder, himself a solitary leading a modest life,<ref>though he was a public figure and one of leading politicians in Catalonia, during his lifetime his own illustrated review, ''La Hormiga de Oro'', has never published his picture</ref> between 1871 and 1902 sold real estate inherited from his ancestors.<ref>the family wealth was being accumulated by generations until 1870, when Luis’ father passed away. In 1871 Llauder sold estate at carrer de Sant Francesc in Mataró (possessed since 1867), in 1876 a house at Muralla del Tigre (held since the early nineteenth century), in 1893 sold three plots in Mataró, in 1900 a garden in Salvi and in 1902 few other pieces, Subińà 1998, p. 93</ref> It seems that a fortune, accumulated by nine generations of the Llauder family, has ultimately been spent as financial reserve sustaining Carlist propaganda machinery in Catalonia.<ref>PhD thesis dedicated to ''La Hormiga'' on almost 400 pages dwells in detail on organization, personal issues and editorial questions, but provides no insight into financial dimension of the business, see Raquel Arias Durá, ''La revista "La Hormiga de Oro". Análisis de contenido y estudio documental del fondo fotográfico'' [PhD thesis Universidad Complutense], Madrid 2013</ref>
==Author== [[File:Jean-Marie Saint-Eve - Temptation on the Mount - Walters 37916.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|''[[Temptation of Christ|the world might be yours]]'']] Llauder kept contributing to different newspapers between mid-1860s and early 20th century,<ref>in 1899 he almost ceased writing, Canal 1998, p. 258</ref> though his opus is mostly [[editorial]]s to ''Correo Catalan''; between 1888 and 1900 he published 537 of them.<ref>Canal 2005, p. 46; in 1888–1898 Llauder used to write 45-50 editorials each year, in every Sunday issue; in 1899 he wrote only 3, in 1900 only 4 and none in 1901 and 1902, Canal 1998, p. 258</ref> Written in [[Spanish language|Spanish]], they were usually clearly attributable,<ref>they were usually signed, sometimes with easily attributable abbreviations like "LL" or "de LL", Canal 1998, p. 259</ref> covered range of topics and served as semi-official Carlist lecture.<ref>Canal 1998, pp. 251-2</ref> Llauder was no political theorist, but his contribution is named "corpus de doctrina carlista"<ref name="Canal 2005, p. 46"/> and compared to that of key Carlist ideologues like [[Antonio Aparisi Guijarro|Aparisi Guijarro]] or Vázquez de Mella.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 251</ref> Some maintain that Llauder underwent ideological evolution, testimonial to schizophrenia of Carlism in the late 19th century;<ref>opinion of Josep M. Fradera in preface to Canal 1998, pp. 9-10</ref> others argue that he demonstrated "coherencia personal i ideologica".<ref name="Canal 2003, p. 30"/> Upon death he was hailed as giant figure in journalism,<ref>Canal 1998, pp. 252-3, Canal 2003, pp. 33-4</ref> today in historiography of Spanish ''periodismo'' he is acknowledged rather briefly.<ref>compare rather casual note in Juan Francisco Fuentes, Javier Fernández Sebastián, ''Historia del periodismo español'', Madrid 1997, {{ISBN|8477384975}}, p. 144</ref>
The primary feature of Llauder's writings was Catholicism; some described his editorial activity as secular [[evangelization]] and dubbed him "sacerdote de la causa".<ref name="Canal 1998, p. 257"/> His religiosity was formatted along fundamentalist lines, based on [[Manichaeism|Manichean]] vision of the world as a battleground between God and satan.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 259, Canal 2005, p. 47</ref> Principal Llauder's foe was liberal Catholicism;<ref>including its vision of religious tolerance and separation of state and Church, Canal 1998, p. 265</ref> campaigns against its embodiment, [[:es:Alejandro Pidal y Mon|Alejandro Pidal]], were by some dubbed as pidalofobia.<ref>e.g. opinion of Arturo Campión, Canal 1998, p. 284</ref> Most events were interpreted within chiliastic perspective, either episodes like [[cholera]] threat in 1890 and attempt against [[Arsenio Martínez-Campos y Antón|Martínez Campos]] in 1893<ref>Canal 1998, pp. 277-8</ref> or milestones of Spanish history like the [[Spanish–American War|1898 crisis]]. The [[Cuban War of Independence|Cuban war]] was seen as a warning (maybe the final one) to Spain, and the [[United States]] was presented as a divine tool, sort of a plague, administered by God to punish the Spaniards for their offences.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 276</ref> [[File:Vayreda6.JPG|thumbnail|160px|''[[Marian Vayreda i Vila|Catalunya muntanyenca]]'']] Llauder's vision of politics was an Integrist one. He viewed Carlism not as a political option, but rather as work of divine providence;<ref>see also references to a “Dios es carlista”, a famous 1873 phrase of Chambord, Canal 1998, p. 278, Canal 2000, pp. 14-15</ref> within this perspective dynastic issues were secondary to questions of principles.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 287, Canal 2000, p. 20</ref> Carlism was the trunk of the [[The Tree and its Fruits|good tree as opposed to the bad tree]]; the trunk of the latter was [[Liberalism in Spain|Liberalism]],<ref>referred to also as an apocalyptic beast, Canal 1998, p. 262</ref> its gardeners were [[Protestantism|Protestants]],<ref>Canal 1998, p. 261</ref> [[freemasonry]]<ref>Canal 1998, p. 264; masonry was "un instrumento del infierno para destruir la obra de Jesucristo", Canal 2000, p. 301</ref> and [[Judaism]],<ref>Canal 1998, pp. 264-5, 275; also the war in Cuba was interpreted along these lines against dechristianisation, masonry and Judaism, Canal 1998, pp. 264-5, 275</ref> while its satanic fruits were [[nihilism]], [[socialism]] and [[anarchism]],<ref>Canal 1998, p. 260</ref> all [[patricide]] ideologies.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 262</ref> The Restoration regime was considered a farce,<ref>Canal 1998, p. 273</ref> while the party system and universal suffrage were deemed corruptive manipulative mechanisms.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 274-5. However, Llauder was convinced that republic, democracy, secularization and the like are all part of the divine plan: “en el orden de la Creación no hay nada casual, ni violento; todo es lógico, todo es regulado... La sublevación de Septiembre (1868) ayudando a la obra de Dios, que indudablemente ha marcado ya la hora de que caiga el árbol nocivo, ha fecundizado la tierra para que adelante la madurez del fruto... esto satisface la doble mira de la providencia: castigar a los pueblos y salvarlos. Si la democracia fuese sólo la república, no seria un castigo, podría ser hasta su salvación”, quoted after Máximo Martín Cabeza, ''Una mítica y simbólica de un milenarismo: el legitimismo'', [in:] Francisco P. Díez de Velasco Abellán (ed.), ''Miedo y religion'', Tenerife 2002, {{ISBN|8479232951}}, available also [http://www.ull.es/congresos/conmirel/martinca1.html#N_27_ here]</ref> Llauder viewed social problems as part of religious issue,<ref>his sensitivity to poverty was well known; according to his contemporaries, “sus rasgos de caridad fueron innumerables, practicandola con tan grande modestia y reserva, que a duras penas tenian conocimiento de sus dadivas las personas de su mayor intimidad", quoted after Canal 1998, p. 238</ref> results of godless Liberalism allowing shameless profiteering,<ref>Canal 1998, p. 267</ref> brought to Spain by foreign and Jewish speculators.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 288. Llauder remained in favour of state protectionism, be it in case of vineyards or railways Canal 1998, p. 268</ref> Spanish economy was described as [[feudalism]] of money, with Jews playing [[senior (status in feudalism)|seniors]] and [[:es:Caciquismo (España)|caciques]] their [[vassal]]s.<ref>Canal 1998, pp. 270-1</ref>
Though some scholars claim that opposing centralization was one of his political principles<ref>the other 3 were abandoning violence, confirming claimants authority and opposing Nocedal, Francesc Closa, ''El finançament de la premsa carlina lleidatana: recursos econòmics i publicitat'', [in:] ''Història Moderna i Contemporània'' 9 (2011), p. 55</ref> and underline that [[Fuero|foralism]] was key component of Catalan Carlism,<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 04.09.99, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/2014/01/02/pagina-18/34483965/pdf.html here]</ref> others argue that regionalism did not form a key thread of his writings.<ref>only one of 537 editorials was dedicated to Catalanism (in 1895), Canal 2005, p. 47. Ongoing polemics, especially when ''La Renaixensa'' took on Vazquez de Mella, was mostly about repulsing attacks rather than about priority attached to the issue, Canal 2005, p. 56, Canal 2006, pp. 202-8. Similar opinion is advanced by Pere Anguera, who underlines "la escasa sensibilidad del principal teórico carlista de la restauración, Luis M. de Llauder, por la cuestión catalana", ''La Vanguardia'' 22.08.99, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1999/08/22/pagina-24/34501143/pdf.html here]</ref> He considered genuine Traditionalists "españoles de sangre y corazón".<ref>going on to explain that it consisted of an amalgama of patriotic, Christian and monarchist values, Canal 1998, p. 287</ref> He viewed nascent [[Catalanism]] with cautious sympathy<ref>Llauder viewed nascent Catalanism as a response of the youth against centralizing Liberalism, Canal 2005, p. 48</ref> as sort of unconscious Carlism; he encouraged the young Catalanists to look for their own way, confident that sooner or later they would join the ranks of Traditionalism and its vision of ''Catalunya muntanyenca''.<ref>Canal 1998, p. 291, Canal 2005, p. 48, Canal 2006, pp. 200-1</ref> It was only after a few years when he concluded with some surprise that key Catalanist tribune ''[[:ca:La Renaixensa|La Renaixensa]]'' was "periódico sistemáticamente anticarlista".<ref>Canal 2005, p. 57</ref>

2016 }} </ref> he denies the relationship was abusive, describing it as consensual "teenage necking".<ref name = forward2>{{cite magazine | last = Gafni | first = Marc | date = November 3, 2016 | title = Marc Gafni Tells His Story — and Experts Respond | url = http://forward.com/opinion/353202/marc-gafni-tells-his-story-and-experts-respond/ | magazine = [[The Forward]] | location = New York | access-date= December 15, 2016 }} </ref><ref name = "DN_McShane">{{cite news | last1 = McShane | first1 = Larry | date = January 2, 2016 | title = New Age guru Marc Gafni allegedly molested two NYC teen girls during the 1980s, denies sexual misconduct allegations | url = http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/marc-gafni-denies-sexual-misconduct-allegations-article-1.2483567 | newspaper = [[New York Daily News]] | access-date = December 29, 2016 }} </ref><ref name = "jewishforward">{{cite news | last1 = Ledger | first1 = Online | date = November 9, 2016 | title = Marc Gafni: I never molested 13-year-old girl
| url = http://www.jewishledger.com/2016/11/marc-gafni-never-molested-13-year-old-girl/ | newspaper = Jewish Ledger | access-date = March 26, 2017 }} </ref>
==Biography== Gafni was born in 1960<ref name = "Oppenheimer2015" /> to [[Holocaust]] survivors in [[Pittsfield, Massachusetts]].<ref name = "POJ-RR">{{citation |url= http://www.haaretz.com/post-orthodoxy-journey-1.115864 |title= Post-Orthodoxy Journey |last= Livneh |first= Neri |date= March 4, 2004 |newspaper= [[Haaretz]]}}</ref> Gafni was educated at Modern-Orthodox [[yeshiva]]s in the [[New York City]] area. In the 1980s, while attending [[Yeshiva University]],<ref name = "POJ-RR" /> Gafni worked with Jewish Public School Youth, an organization providing Jewish social clubs in public schools.<ref name="NYP">{{cite web |url= http://www.nypost.com/news/regionalnews/66361.htm |title= Fiend Rabbi On Run |accessdate= December 28, 2016 |last= Montefinise |first= Angela |date= May 21, 2006 |publisher= [[New York Post]] |pages = 25 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060614154413/http://www.nypost.com/news/regionalnews/66361.htm |archivedate= 2006-06-14 }} </ref> In 1988, Gafni also worked as a rabbi in [[Boca Raton]], [[Florida]].<ref name="Rosenblatt04" /> After making [[aliyah]], Gafni served as rabbi of the [[West Bank]] settlement of [[Tzofim]].<ref name = "Ynet-Raved">{{cite news | last1 = Raved | first1 = Ahiya | last2 = Cohen | first2 = Avi | date = May 18, 2006 | title = Rabbi Gafni accused of sexual assault | url = http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3252577,00.html | department = News | website = [[Ynetnews]] | access-date = December 28, 2016 }} </ref> When Gafni moved to Israel he hebraicized his name. "Winiarz," Polish for "vintner," is related to the [[Hebrew]] word {{transl|he|ISO|''gefen''}} ({{rtl-lang|he|גפן}}), which means "grape"—thus the name "Gafni." Gafni has three children from previous marriages<ref name = "POJ-RR" /> and one child with Mariana Caplan.<ref name = "Caplan">{{cite web | title = About the Founders | url = http://centerforintegralwisdom.org/ciw-founders/ | publisher = Center for Integral Wisdom | year = 2015 | accessdate = December 29, 2015 }} </ref><ref name = "CIWS Bio">{{cite web |url = http://www.ievolve.org/leadership/executive-officers/#Marc_Gafni_DPhil |title = Marc Gafni, D.Phil. |year = 2013 |work = Executive Officers |publisher = Center for World Spirituality |accessdate = February 27, 2013 }} </ref>
===Education=== Gafni majored in philosophy as an undergraduate and earned his doctorate in philosophy from [[Oxford University]].<ref name = "POJ-RR" /><ref name = psychologytoday>{{cite web | url = https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/ethical-wisdom/201509/evolutionary-love-interview-dr-marc-gafni | title = Evolutionary Love: An Interview With Dr. Marc Gafni | last = Matousek | first = Mark | date = September 8, 2015 | publisher = Psychology Today | access-date = December 29, 2016 }} </ref> He claims to hold rabbinic certification from the [[Chief Rabbinate of Israel]],<ref name = "GafniBio" /> but Gafni has since returned his ''[[semikhah]]'' to "spare his former teacher any further embarrassment".<ref name="Rosenblatt04"/>
==Teachings and prominent works== Gafni's teachings are often described as [[Integral theory (Ken Wilber)|integral]] or world [[spirituality]], incorporating traditional religious studies to contemporary themes, and are aimed at spirituality for people who do not identify with one specific religion.<ref name = "POJ-RR"/><ref name=haaretz>{{cite web|last=Ganihar|first=Tomer|title=Death of the spirit|url=http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/week-s-end/death-of-the-spirit-1.366510|publisher=Haaretz|date=June 7, 2011}}</ref> Gafni describes himself and his students as "dual citizens" of both their native traditional religion and the broader themes of "world spirituality".<ref name = "POJ-RR"/><ref name=dual>{{cite web|title=A Passport for Dual Citizenship with Michael Murphy & Marc Gafni|url=http://www.ievolve.org/tag/dual-citizenship/|publisher=Center for World Spirituality|date=August 8, 2011}}</ref> He advocates a new set of teachings around [[Eros (concept)|eros]], [[Human sexuality|sexuality]] and [[Intimate relationship|relationships]] in his book ''Mystery of Love'' and CD set ''Erotic and the Holy''.<ref name=jweek>{{cite web|last=Wall|first=Alexandra|title=Let love, sex and holiness make your life full, says rabbi|url=http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/19850/let-love-sex-and-holiness-make-your-life-full-says-rabbi/|publisher=J Weekly|date=May 9, 2003}}</ref><ref name = "Rosnblum2006">{{cite web | url = http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Columnists/Think-Again-Sexualizing-the-public-square | title = Think Again: 'Sexualizing' the public square | accessdate = December 28, 2016 | last = Rosenblum | first = Jonathan | authorlink = Jonathan Rosenblum | date = July 13, 2006 | publisher = [[The Jerusalem Post]] }} See also Gafni, ''The Erotic And The Holy: Kabbalistic Tantra for Everyday Living''</ref> At the core of his world spirituality message is what Gafni refers to as the unique self, "a series of integral discernments between separateness and uniqueness, ego and Unique Self, and personal and impersonal man."<ref name = "GafniAbsract">{{cite web | url = http://uniqueself.com/unique-self-theory/unique-self-basics/marc-gafni-on-unique-self/the-evolutionary-emergent-of-unique-self/ | title = The Evolutionary Emergent of Unique Self (Abstract) | last = Gafni | first = Marc | year = 2011 | website = Unique Self | access-date = December 20, 2016 }} </ref> Gafni believes that "the sexual is the ultimate Spiritual Master" and has written "I was convinced from an early age that religion had lost what I believed must have been its original erotic vitality…I knew that the sexual, if liberated and ethically expressed, must somehow hold the mystery of return to the much larger-than-sexual Eros."<ref name = "TantricGuru" />
In 2010, Gafni, together with Mariana Caplan—the mother of his son Zion,<ref name = "Caplan"/> Sally Kempton, and Lori Galperin, founded the Center for World Spirituality.<ref name = "CSWFounding">{{cite web | url = http://centerforintegralwisdom.org/ciw-founders/ | title = Founders | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | year = 2015 | website = Center for Integral Wisdom | access-date = December 19, 2016 }} </ref> That year, Gafni and [[Ken Wilber]] founded a Wisdom Council to envision a world spirituality based on Integral Principles.<ref name = "CaplanCommonGround">{{cite magazine | last = Caplan | first = Mariana | year = 2011 | issue = December 2010/January 2011 | title = Los Angeles Makes Movies. San Francisco Makes Movements. | url = http://onlinedigitaleditions2.com/commonground/archive/web-12-2010/ | magazine = Common Ground Magazine | pages = 64–65 | location = [[Mill Valley, California]] | publisher = Rob Sidon | access-date= December 19, 2016 }} </ref> The Wisdom Council is part of the Center for World Spirituality and includes members such as Gafni, Wilber, [[Tony Robbins]], [[Deepak Chopra]], [[Warren Farrell]], Lori Galperin, Sally Kempton and other leaders.<ref name=wisdomcouncil>{{cite web|title=Wisdom Council|url=http://www.ievolve.org/leadership/world-spirituality-council/|publisher=iEvolve}}</ref> The co-chair of Center for World Spirituality is [[Whole Foods]] [[CEO]] [[John Mackey (businessman)|John Mackey]].<ref name=mac>{{cite web|title=What is a purpose-driven business?: John Mackey and Marc Gafni in Dialogue, Part 2|url=http://www.ievolve.org/world-spirituality-unplugged-what-is-a-purpose-driven-business-john-mackey-and-marc-gafni-in-dialogue-part-1%E2%80%B3/|publisher=iEvolve|date=October 19, 2012}}</ref>
Gafni was a Scholar in Residence at the Integral Institute and the Director of the Integral Spiritual Experience but left after the 2011 allegations of his sexual impropriety.<ref name = "JW 09132011">{{cite web |url = http://www.thejewishweek.com/news/brief/new_sexual_complaints_against_marc_gafni |title = New Sexual Complaints Against Marc Gafni |last1 = Rosenblatt |first1 = Gary |authorlink1 = Gary Rosenblatt |date = September 13, 2011 |publisher = [[The Jewish Week]] |accessdate = December 28, 2016 }} </ref>
===Writing=== Gafni is the author of eight books on spirituality and religion, including the 2001 ''Soul Prints''.<ref name="catalyst"/> Marc Gafni's second English-language book, ''The Mystery of Love'', was later converted to an audio lecture series called ''The Erotic and the Holy'', published by [[Sounds True]]. He also co-authored ''Who is Afraid of Lilith? Rereading the Kabbalah of the Feminine Shadow'' with Ohad Ezrachi.<ref name = "FreeLibraryLilith">{{cite web | url = https://www.thefreelibrary.com/When+the+Rabbi+Met+Lilith.-a0133901938 | title = When the Rabbi Met Lilith. | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | date = July 11, 2005 | website = The Free Library | publisher = [[PR Newswire]] | access-date = December 21, 2016 }} </ref> He wrote ''Radical Kabbalah'', a two-volume work published by Integral Publishers in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Integral Publishers|url=http://integralpublishers.com/ip_books/}}</ref> In 2012, he published ''Your Unique Self: The Radical Path to Personal Enlightenment'' with a foreword written by Wilber.<ref name = "YUS_Forward">{{cite web| url = http://uniqueself.com/about-the-book/take-a-look/| title = Take a Look at the Table of Contents| year = 2016| website = Unique Self| publisher = Center for Integral Wisdom| access-date = January 4, 2016}}</ref> It won the 2012 USA Book News Best Book of the Year award in the Spirituality: General category.<ref name = "USABook2012">{{cite web | url = http://www.usabooknews.com/images/2012_results.pdf | title = 2012 Reseults | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | website = [[USA Book News]] | access-date = December 19, 2016 | format = PDF | quote = }} </ref>
===Television and speaking=== While in Israel, Gafni hosted {{transl|he|ISO|''Tahat Gafno''}} ({{lang-he|תחת גפנו|lit=under his vine}}), a television program broadcast on Israel's [[Channel 2 (Israel)|Channel 2]].<ref name = "POJ-RR"/> Gafni also did a series of weekly television spots with Israeli comedian Gil Kopatch on biblical wisdom for every day life.<ref name = "Kopatch2005">{{cite news | last = Kopatch | first = Gil | date = June 2, 2005 | title = Why Am I Not a Buddhist? | url = http://www.haaretz.com/why-am-i-not-a-buddhist-1.160186 | newspaper = [[Haaretz]] | access-date = December 28, 2016 }} </ref> Gafni appeared in a series of spiritual [[public service announcement]]s on Israeli television in the wake of several terrorist attacks.<ref>[http://www.marcgafni.com/video_audio/video/series-1-4-spots-dubbed-in-english/ "These four videos (in Hebrew with English subtitles) are part of a series of seven spots made for Israel’s leading television station in the middle of a wave of terrorist bombings."] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130411081027/http://www.marcgafni.com/video_audio/video/series-1-4-spots-dubbed-in-english/ |date=2013-04-11 }} MarcGafni.com Retrieved March 2013</ref>
In 2005, Gafni spoke with the [[14th Dalai Lama|Dalai Lama]] about the perception of love.<ref name = "Kopatch2005" /> In 2010 Gafni did a series with Chopra entitled ''Love and Evolution''.<ref name=dee>{{cite web|last=Gafni|first=Marc|title=Join Deepak Chopra and Dr. Marc Gafni on the Future of Love|url=http://www.marcgafni.com/englishenglishhebrewhebrew-189/|publisher=Marc Gafni|date=May 13, 2010}}</ref> In 2013, Gafni and [[Eben Pagan]] founded an event called "Actualize: The Source Code of Success".<ref>{{cite web|first= |last= |title=Actualize: The Source Code of Success|url=http://www.ievolve.org/actualize-the-source-code-of-success/|publisher=iEvolve}}</ref>
==Sexual assault allegations== Gafni has been accused of sexual assault multiple times dating back to the 1980s.<ref name="Rosenblatt04"/><ref name = "Oppenheimer2015" /><ref name="NYP" /><ref name = "JW 09132011" />
In early January 2016, Judy Mitzner alleged that she was one of two teenage girls whom Gafni molested in New York City in 1986.<ref name = "Prince">{{cite news |last=Prince |first=Cathryn J. |date=January 6, 2016 |title=Controversial ex-rabbi Gafni and an alleged victim square off |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/controversial-ex-rabbi-gafni-and-an-alleged-victim-square-off/ |work=[[The Times of Israel]] |access-date=February 7, 2018}}</ref> She reiterated those claims on an appearance on the [[Dr. Phil (talk show)|Dr. Phil]] show of January 19, 2018, in which Gafni also appeared.<ref name = "Pink">{{cite magazine|last=Pink|first=Aiden|date=January 21, 2018|title=Accused Child Molester Marc Gafni Defends Himself On 'Dr. Phil'|url=https://forward.com/fast-forward/392482/accused-child-molester-marc-gafni-defends-himself-on-dr-phil/|magazine=[[The Forward]]|location=[[New York City]]|access-date=February 7, 2018}}</ref>
Also in January 2016, an unnamed woman wrote that she was married to Gafni from 1999 to 2004 in an [[opinion piece]] in ''[[The Times of Israel]]'' . The article was in response to a ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' article about Gafni the preceding week.<ref name="Oppenheimer2015" /> She catalogued what she described as her story of abuse and wrote that she had gone public to "Protect some girl. Protect some woman. Some student. Some unsuspecting soul."<ref name="ToIVoice">{{cite news|url=http://blogs.timesofisrael.com/from-one-gafni-victim/|title=A voice for Gafni's victims, from one who was there|last=|first=|date=January 1, 2016|work=[[The Times of Israel]]|accessdate=January 3, 2016}}</ref> Within two weeks, Sara Kabakov revealed in ''[[The Forward]]'' that she was the formerly unnamed teenage girl who had been abused by Gafni in the early 1980s, beginning when she was thirteen years old.<ref name="Kabakov">{{cite magazine|last=Kabakov|first=Sara|date=January 12, 2016|title='I Was 13 When Marc Gafni's Abuse Began'|url=http://forward.com/opinion/329620/i-was-13-when-marc-gafnis-abuse-began|magazine=[[The Forward]]|location=[[New York City]]|access-date=December 21, 2016}}</ref> Gafni commented, "she was 14 going on 35, and I never forced her."<ref name="Friedman2015" /> In a subsequent article, ''The Forward'' published Gafni's response together with the analysis of sexual abuse experts.<ref name="forward2" /> Gafni included polygraph results to support his claim that his relationship with Kabakov was consensual.<ref name="GafniPoly">{{cite web|url=http://www.marcgafni.com/resp/report-of-polygraph-results-october-2007/|title=Report of Polygraph Results October 2007|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|year=2015|access-date=December 28, 2016}} </ref><ref name="Barland2">{{cite web|url=http://www.marcgafni.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/02/Gafni-report-2-final-Barland.pdf|title=Report of Polygraph Examination: Marc Gafni|last=Barland|first=Gordon H.|date=December 14, 2007|website=MarcGafni.com|format=PDF|access-date=December 28, 2016|quote=…this was a poor issue for the polygraph. The polygraph is believed to be most accurate when a person denies committing a specific physical act.…It would be more appropriate to examine Sarah as to whether she had written a letter, than him as to whether he had read it. More importantly, testing on the contents of a letter received nearly 30 years ago is inappropriate because memory is easily modified over time – often significantly – based on additional knowledge and experience.…We agreed that if he wished to be tested on this issue, I would have to include a caveat to the effect that because of the complexity of the issue, one could not have as much confidence in the results.…'''Conclusion''' It is my professional opinion that Mr. Gafni answered the relevant questions truthfully. Because of the nearly three decades that have elapsed since Ms. Kabakow's letter would have been received, confidence in this conclusion is necessarily somewhat less than would otherwise be the case.}} </ref> Afterwards, Kabakov responded to Gafni's comments and reiterated her claim that the relationship was not consensual.<ref name="Kabakov2">{{cite magazine|last=Kabakov|first=Sara|date=November 14, 2016|title=Marc Gafni Told His Side of the Story. Now His Accuser Responds.|url=http://forward.com/opinion/354282/marc-gafni-told-his-side-of-the-story-now-his-accuser-responds/|magazine=[[The Forward]]|location=[[New York City]]|access-date=April 20, 2017}} </ref> In February 2017, the [[National Coalition for Men]] published an article by Gafni in which he defended himself, calling the allegations "a long-standing smear campaign".<ref name="NCFM">{{cite web|url=http://ncfm.org/2017/02/news/uncategorized/ncfm-member-marc-gafni-fake-facts-unchecked-falsehoods-that-destroy-lives/|title=NCFM Member Marc Gafni, Fake Facts: Unchecked Falsehoods that Destroy Lives|last=Gafni|first=Marc|date=February 10, 2017|publisher=[[National Coalition for Men]]|access-date=March 26, 2017}}</ref> The following month, he published another rebuttal on [[Medium.com]].<ref name="medium">{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/@eytanyair/marc-gafni-responds-missing-facts-motives-malice-ex-wife-c43f191f0c3#.3wg795c1o|title=The Missing Facts, Motives, and Hidden Malice in My Ex-Wife's Articles about Me, Marc Gafni|last=Gafni|first=Marc|date=March 9, 2017|publisher=[[Medium.com]]|access-date=March 26, 2017}}</ref> This accusation was also addressed on the Dr. Phil episode of January 19, 2018.<ref name = "Pink" />
In 2006, after he moved to Israel, Gafni was accused by three women who attended the {{transl|he|ISO|''Bayit Hadash''}} ({{lang-he|בית חדש|lit=new home}}) spiritual center in [[Jaffa]], which Gafni opened in the late 1990s. Gafni acknowledged relationships with some of the women.<ref name="NYP" /> However, he characterized the relationships as consensual and supported his claim by posting [[polygraph]] results on his website.<ref name="Barland1b">{{cite web|url=http://www.marcgafni.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/02/Gafni-report-1b-final-Barland.pdf|title=Report of Polygraph Examination: Marc Gafni|last=Barland|first=Gordon H.|date=October 30, 2007|website=MarcGafni.com|format=PDF|access-date=December 28, 2016|quote=In my opinion Mr. Gafni answered the relevant questions truthfully. This opinion is tempered by the fact that I had no access to the original complaints.}} </ref> Because of the allegations, and because Gafni fled the country to avoid prosecution,<ref name="Ynet-Raved" /><ref name="haaretz" /> he was dismissed from {{transl|he|ISO|''Bayit Hadash''}},<ref name="Heruti">{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/new-age-rabbi-mordechi-gafni-accused-of-sex-crimes-1.188097|title=New-age Rabbi Mordechi Gafni accused of sex crimes|last=Singer-Heruti|first=Roni|date=May 19, 2006|publisher=''[[Haaretz]]''|accessdate=March 20, 2013}} </ref> which closed within days.<ref name="Shma">{{cite journal|last=Ner-David|first=Jacob|date=December 1, 2006|title=Genug: Time for a Change|url=http://www.shma.com/dec_06/genug.htm|journal=Sh'ma: A Journal of Jewish Responsibility|location=[[Boston]]|publisher=Sh'ma Institute|archiveurl=http://www.shma.com/2006/12/genug-time-for-a-change/|archivedate=October 8, 2008|accessdate=December 28, 2016}} </ref> Back in the United States, Gafni sent a remorseful letter to his congregation saying he regretted his actions.<ref name="Heruti" /><ref name="Siegal">{{cite web|url=http://www.forward.com/articles/965/|title=Rabbi Fired Over Sex Claims, Defenders Offer Mea Culpa|last=Siegal|first=Jennifer|date=May 19, 2006|publisher=''[[The Forward]]''|accessdate=2008-01-13}} </ref> Gafni later claimed the letter was not an admission of guilt but an attempt to cool the controversy.<ref name="gafniletter">{{cite web|url=http://www.marcgafni.com/englishenglishhebrewhebrew-430/|title=Why I Signed the Letter|last=Gafni|first=Marc|date=May 27, 2008|accessdate=March 11, 2013}}</ref>
Gafni was the subject of new allegations of sexual misconduct in 2011.<ref name="JW 09132011" /> As a result, Integral Life, one of Gafni's promoters, deleted his contributions from its website and announced that it was distancing itself from him.<ref name="JW 09132011" /> Tami Simon, CEO of [[Sounds True]], canceled her planned publication of Gafni's book, ''Your Unique Self'', and issued a statement denouncing him.<ref name="JW 09142011">{{cite web|url=http://www.thejewishweek.com/blogs/gary-rosenblatt/marc-gafni-again|title=Marc Gafni, Again|last1=Rosenblatt|first1=Gary|authorlink1=Gary Rosenblatt|date=September 14, 2011|publisher=''[[The Jewish Week]]''|accessdate=February 27, 2013}} </ref> The board of directors of the Center for World Spirituality, an organization co-founded by Gafni and of which he is CEO, issued a statement of "unequivocal support" for Gafni.<ref name="support">{{cite web|url=http://www.ievolve.org/a-cws-board-statement-of-unequivocal-support-for-dr-marc-gafni/|title=A CWS Board Statement of Unequivocal Support for Dr. Marc Gafni|date=September 2011|website=ievolve.org|publisher=Center for Integral Wisdom|access-date=December 28, 2016}} </ref> Wilber first separated from Gafni,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://integrallife.com/member/ken-wilber/blog/ken-wilbers-response-marc-gafni-debacle?|title=Ken Wilber's Response to the Marc Gafni Debacle|last=Wilber|first=Ken|date=October 17, 2011|publisher=Ken Wilber}}</ref> but the two eventually reconciled and Wilber rejoined Gafni at the Center for World Spirituality.<ref name="wilber11">{{cite web|url=http://www.kenwilber.com/blog/show/701|title=Ken Wilber Statement on Marc Gafni and the Center for World Spirituality|last=Wilber|first=Ken|date=December 27, 2011|publisher=Ken Wilber}}</ref> ''Your Unique Self'' was ultimately published by Integral Publishers.<ref name="integralbook">{{cite web|url=http://integralpublishers.com/ip_books/your-unique-self|title=Your Unique Self|publisher=Integral Publishers}}</ref>

Rereading the Kabbalah of the Feminine Shadow'' *2006 ''The Erotic and the Holy'' {{ISBN|978-1591792895}} *2012 ''Your Unique Self: The Radical Path to Personal Enlightenment'' {{ISBN|978-1467522779}} *2012 ''Radical Kabbalah'' {{ISBN|978-1467522748}} *2014 ''Loving Your Way to Enlightenment'' {{ISBN|978-1502305145}} *2014 ''Tears: Reclaiming Ritual, Integral Religion, and Rosh Hashanah'' {{ISBN|978-0989682749}} *2014 ''Self in Integral Evolutionary Mysticism'' {{ISBN|978-0989682787}} *2014 ''Your Unique Self: An Integral Path to Success 3.0'' {{ISBN|978-0990441939}} {{div col end}}
